Module information

Can you write a great essay..?  Can you be persuasive and, at the same time, factually correct..?  The BIOS0006 module introduces the skills and techniques needed to communicate well – not only to the scientific community but also to a wider audience.  You will be supervised by a member of staff from the Division of Biosciences or an associated department. The class meets for 7 formal sessions over 2 terms, to introduce core skills and to plan effective writing.  Most of the time, students will practice the core skills in their own time and later liaise with their supervisor for feedback.  Supervisors will guide students on cutting-edge research in a defined field of expertise.

Students should gain the following knowledge and skills:

  1. Detailed understanding of a modern theme of scientific research in Physiology, Pharmacology, Neuroscience, or Cell Biology
  2. Use of electronic databases to research the literature for information on Bioscience and its related subjects.
  3. Ability to prepare a scientific dissertation to a specified length and format (as a word-processed document), by a given deadline.
  4. Ability to give oral and written presentations to both scientific and non-expert audiences.

 

The module is an option for second year students on the Biomedical Sciences Neuroscience or Pharmacology programmes. Students should have completed PHOL0001 (Mammalian Physiology), and/or PHAR0002 (Introduction to Mechanisms in Drug Action) and/or NEUR0004 (Introduction to Neuroscience).  The module can be taken in conjunction with PHOL0003 (Animal and Human Physiology).
